discussion.significance.user_answer_positive: This study examined the impact of the route of sub-lethal pesticide exposure (either pollen or syrup) on B. impatiens. It examined the impact of the delivery route on different colony-level outcomes or life stages. It found evidence that the route of delivery impacted brood and adults differently, with increased influence of pollen on brood and syrup on adult workers. Use of both pollen and syrup in ecotox testing is needed to ensure all treatment effects are captured.
discussion.significance.user_reason_positive: This study highlights that in ecotox oral testing the vehicle of delivery is syrup which mimics nectar (adult food). The addition of pollen as a vehicle would ensure brood-effcets were captured.

discussion.future_research.user_answer_positive:
Future work on colony-level fitness is needed:
i) to investigate the 2 week delay observed in the maximum pollen consumption and subsequent drone emergence. Perhaps by limiting pollen or syrup availability in the weeks before drone emergence.
ii) to determine how windows of exposure effect the number and weight of reproductives produced.
iii) to track food consumption over time to enable colony level exposure to be assessed
iv) that focuses on pollen consumption and drone numbers, emergence, size and weight as endpoints to allow for direct comparison between studies.
v) that incorporates route of exposure into the experimental design
vi) to assess potential exposure route differences in nectar paot utilisation

discussion.limitations.user_answer_positive: The paper discusses the limitations in comparison of delivery route, primarily that this study design cannot isolate how much of each source was consumed by either adults or larvae. Also caste has an impact, as reproductives involved in egg laying require more pollen to meet the requirements of oocyte production. Workers masticate pollen to build the nest and feed the brood and it is unknown how much they consume. It is assumed that larvae consume more pollen than syrup, but it is not known how food predigestation by workers may effect the level of pesticides it contains.
discussion.limitations.user_reason_positive: The main limitations are the lack of knowledge around how much of each source of food is consumed by bees of different castes and developemnt stage. The impact of detoxification of food by worker bees prior to feeding brood is also a limitation.
